First, select the \"Generate\" button. This will cause an array of a size between one and ten filled with random values to show up on the screen. The value in the drop-down menu is the one that the algorithm will search for. If you would like to change this value, then select another value form the drop-down menu. Next, click \"Start\" to begin the animation. If you would like to go back to the beginning of the animation, then click the \"Rewind\" button. If you would like to stop on a certain frame, then use the \"Stop\" button to do so.\n\n The array will start as a dark blue color. As elements are checked for equality with the value-sought, then they will turn light-blue. Finally, if the value sought is found it turns pink.

First, select the \"Generate\" button. This will cause an array of a size between one and ten filled with random values to show up on the screen. The value in the drop-down menu is the one that the algorithm will search for. If you would like to change this value, then select another value form the drop-down menu. Next, click \"Start\" to begin the animation. If you would like to go back to the beginning of the animation, then click the \"Rewind\" button. If you would like to stop on a certain frame, then use the \"Stop\" button to do so.\n\n The array will start as a dark blue color. As elements are checked for equality with the value-sought, then they will turn light-blue. Finally, if the value sought is found it turns pink.

First, select the \"Generate\" button. This will cause an array of a size between one and ten filled with random values to show up on the screen. Next, click \"Start\" to begin the animation. If you would like to go back to the beginning of the animation, then click the \"Rewind\" button. If you would like to stop on a certain frame, then use the \"Stop\" button to do so.\n\n The array will start as a dark blue color. Elements will be selected in pairs for comparison and swapped if the value on the right is smaller than the value on the left. Then, once the array is sorted, it will turn light-blue.

First, select the \"Generate\" button. This will cause an array of a size between one and ten filled with random values to show up on the screen. Next, click \"Start\" to begin the animation. If you would like to go back to the beginning of the animation, then click the \"Rewind\" button. If you would like to stop on a certain frame, then use the \"Stop\" button to do so.\n\n The array will start as a dark blue color. The sorted portion of the array will be displayed in light-blue. Selected elements to insert into the array will be selected in pink, then inserted in pink to their correct location in the array. Finally, the sorted array will be displayed in light-blue.

First, select the \"Generate\" button. This will cause an array of a size between one and ten filled with random values to show up on the screen. Next, click \"Start\" to begin the animation. If you would like to go back to the beginning of the animation, then click the \"Rewind\" button. If you would like to stop on a certain frame, then use the \"Stop\" button to do so.\n\n The array will start as a dark blue color. The sorted portion of the array will be displayed in light-blue. The elements unsorted will be highlighted pink, then the sought will be highlighted pink and turn light-blue when it is placed into its proper location in the sorted array.

First, select the \"Generate\" button. This will cause an array of either 1, 5, or 6 to be generated. Then, if unsatisfied with the generated value, select the size of array you would like to sort. Next, click \"Start\" to begin the animation. If you would like to go back to the beginning of the animation, then click the \"Rewind\" button. If you would like to stop on a certain frame, then use the \"Stop\" button to do so.\n\n The array will start as a dark blue color. The sorted portion of the array will be displayed in light-blue. As elements are being swapped and merged, they will turn different colors that correspond to the step of the algorithm.

First, select the \"Generate\" button. This will cause an array of a size between one and ten filled with random values to show up on the screen. Next, click \"Start\" to begin the animation. If you would like to go back to the beginning of the animation, then click the \"Rewind\" button. If you would like to stop on a certain frame, then use the \"Stop\" button to do so.\n\n The array will start as a dark blue color. The pivot value will be selected in pink. The portion of the array being ordered will be highlighted in light-blue. Finally, the sorted array will turn light-blue.

Linear search is an O(n) algorithm that looks through all the elements in an unsorted array for a specific value. If that value is found, then its location in the array is returned. If not, then -1 is returned.

Binary search is an O(log n) algorithm that looks through all the elements in a pre-sorted array for a specific value. If that value is found, then its location in the array is returned. If not, then -1 is returned. The runtime comes from the fact that, due to the fact the array is ordered, half of the array can be discarded at each step, since we can determine in which half the value should be found.
Bubble sort is a O(n^2) algorithm where values are swapped in pairs and, at each step, the largest values \"bubble\" to the rightmost side of the array. The array ends up sorted at the end.

Insertion sort is a O(n^2) algorithm where the first element is counted as sorted. Then, each element in the array is selected and inserted into the correct location in the sorted array. This algorithm is like how you organize a hand of cards, since you start with one card, and then, as you select additional cards, you insert them into the correct location in the hand one-by-one. At the end, you have a sorted hand of cards or, in our example, hand of cards.

Selection sort is a O(n^2) algorithm where the sought element from an unsorted portion of an array is selected and inserted into the sorted portion of the array. This is like how you would sort a group of coins if you had a pile in front of you. You would first look through all the coins, pick out a penny, and then place it in a sorted position. Next, you would look through and select all pennies this way. Next, you would repeat this process for nickles, dimes, and finally quarters.

Merge sort is a O(n logn) algorithm where the array is broken into pieces recursively with a base case of 1 element, which is automatically sorted and an alternate case of merging sorted halves, until the whole array is built up again, but this time sorted.
Quicksort is a O(n logn) algorithm where a pivot is selected and sections are recursively sorted by having all elements smaller and larger than the pivot organized on the proper side of the pivot.
Depth first search is an O(...) algorithm where ...
Breadth first search is an O(...) algorithm where ...
Topological ordering is an O(...) algorithm where ...
